text.text_translated:
One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins changed TV channels.
It was during the US war in Iraq.
She found only two kinds of TV shows.
She saw shows with young people.
They tried to win one million dollars.
She also saw news about the war.
These two things started to mix in her mind.
They felt wrong together.
Then she got an idea for a new book.
This book is by Suzanne Collins.

feedback.feedback: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7319 is below the required 0.75. Your version changes ‘the US invasion of Iraq’ to ‘the US war in Iraq’, losing the precise reference. It also breaks ‘reality programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars’ into two sentences, diluting the original concept. Suggestion: Restore the phrase ‘US invasion of Iraq’ exactly. Suggestion: Retain ‘reality programmes of young people competing to win a million dollars’ as one unit to preserve the core message.

best_attempt.text_translated:
One night in 2003, Suzanne Collins changed TV channels.
It was during the US war in Iraq.
She found only two kinds of programmes.
She saw reality programmes of young people.
They competed to win a million dollars.
She also saw news about the war.
These two things started to mix in her mind.
They felt wrong together.
Then she got the idea for The Hunger Games.
The Hunger Games is a book by Suzanne Collins.
